TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, superactive, frigid Pachic Haploxerolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Elzinga silt loam, native bigtooth maple and grasses.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
O1--1 inch to 0; partially decomposed leaves and twigs.
A1--0 to 22 inches; very dark gray (10YR 3/1) silt loam, black (10YR 2/1) moist; weak fine and medium granular structure; soft, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine, medium, and coarse roots; slightly acid (pH 6.4); gradual smooth boundary.  (20 to 36 inches thick)
A21--22 to 26 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) silt loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine and medium roots; many fine and medium interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.3); gradual smooth boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
A22--26 to 48 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) cobbly silt loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, sticky and slightly plastic; many fine and medium roots; many fine and medium interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.3); gradual smooth boundary.  (10 to 25 inches thick)
A&B--48 to 62 inches; about 70 percent A2 horizon and 30 percent B2t horizon.  The A2 portion is pale brown (10YR 6/3) very cobbly, very fine sandy loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; the B2t portion is brown (7.5YR 5/4) very cobbly clay loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; thin continuous clay films; many fine and medium roots; many fine and medium interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.4); gradual wavy boundary.  (12 to 25 inches thick)
R--62 to 65 inches; fractured sandstone with B2t horizon material as above extending into cracks.  More than 90 percent sandstone rock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Cache County, Utah; 3 miles south of Wellsville, Utah; 1,200 feet south and 2,000 feet east of the northwest corner of section 27, T.10N., R.1W.Located on very steep north or northeast facing mountain slopes.  Wellsville USGS quad - lat. 41 degrees 34 minutes 46 seconds N. and long. 111 degrees 57 minutes 4 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mollic epipedon is 20 to 36 inches thick.  The combined thickness of A1, A2, and B2t horizons is more than 60 inches.  Coarse fragments are mainly cobble and gravel size angular sandstone rock fragments, ranging from 30 to 50 percent in the A21 horizon and 35 to 60 percent in the A22 and B2t horizons.  The mean annual soil temperature is 40 to 45 degrees F., and the mean summer temperature at 20 inches depth is 59 to 63 degrees F.  The soils are usually moist, but are dry in some subhorizons for 30 to 40 days during the late summer months.  The 01 horizon is 1/2 to 2 inches thick.  The A1 horizon has value of 1 or 2 moist, and chroma of 1 or 2 dry and 1 or 1.5 moist.  It has weak to moderate, fine to medium granular structure.  It is slightly acid to medium acid.  The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 3 or 4 moist, and chroma of 3 or 4.  It is silt loam, cobbly silt loam or cobbly very fine sandy loam.  It has weak fine or medium subangular blocky structure or is massive.  It is slightly acid to medium acid.  The A2 horizon tongues into the B2t horizon.  The B2t horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 or 4.  It is very cobbly clay loam to very cobbly loam, with 35 to 60 percent cobble and gravel.  It has moderate medium to fine subangular blocky structure.  It is slightly acid to medium acid.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Flygare, LaPlatta, Lucky Star, Maughan, Scave, and Smarts series.  Flygare soils have moist chroma of 2 or more in the mollic epipedon and an average summer temperature of less than 59 degrees F.  LaPlatta soils lack albic horizons and have horizons of carbonate accumulation.  Lucky Star and Scave soils have mollic epipedons less than 20 inches thick with moist chroma of 2 or more and an average summer temperature of less than 59 degrees F.  Maughan soils have cobbly clay argillic horizons containing less than 35 percent coarse fragments.  Smarts soils have mollic epipedons with chroma of 2 or more, lack albic horizons, and have very cobbly heavy loam argillic horizons.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Elzinga soils are at elevations of 5,000 to 7,500 feet above sea level on very steep north or northeast facing mountain slopes, with gradients of 30 to 60 percent.  They formed in colluvium and residuum from sandstone and limestone.  The climate is moist subhumid, with an average annual precipitation of 20 to 26 inches.  The mean annual temperature is 40 to 45 degrees F., and the average summer temperature is 60 to 62 degrees F.  The frost free season is 70 to 120 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the competing Maughan soils and the Agassiz, Datwyler, and Sheep Creek soils have a mollic epipedon with chroma of 2 or more and lack A2 horizons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow or medium runoff; moderate or moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for rangeland and watershed.  The native vegetation is bigtooth maple, slender wheatgrass, mountain bromegrass, blue wildrye, chokecherry, snowberry, sweet anise, mint, elk weed, and cow cabbage.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern Utah.  These soils are inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: The Elzinga soils were formerly classified as Brunizems intergrading to Gray Wooded soils.
The Type Location was updated 1/2004.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
